Introduction

An anal fissure is a superficial, longitudinal tear in the anal mucosa distal to the dentate line (

figure 1
).  It typically occurs in the posterior midline of the anal verge and is most often caused by mechanical trauma, typically from chronic constipation (eg, straining) or the passage of hard stools.  Patients often present with severe, tearing pain during defecation and bright red rectal bleeding.

Pathogenesis



Anal fissures commonly result from mechanical trauma to the anal mucosa, most often due to hard stools and constipation.  Straining generates elevated anal sphincter pressure, which can stretch and tear the mucosa, producing a linear fissure.  The majority of fissures occur at the posterior midline of the anal verge, where blood flow is relatively reduced, making the tissue more vulnerable to injury.  Fissures located laterally or anteriorly are atypical and suggest a secondary etiology for anal fissure, such as inflammatory bowel disease, infection, or malignancy.

Risk factors



Local mucosal trauma:



  • Constipation and passage of hard stools.
  • Vaginal delivery.
  • Anal intercourse.
  • Prolonged diarrhea and poor anal hygiene:  Promote irritation and inflammation, which lower the threshold for fissure development.


Underlying medical conditions:



  • Inflammatory bowel disease (eg, Crohn disease):  Chronically inflamed mucosa is fragile and more prone to tearing.
  • Infection (eg, HIV, syphilis).
  • Malignancy (eg, anal cancer).

Pathology



The majority of anal fissures begin as painful, superficial tears in the anal mucosa.  Pain arises both from direct irritation of exposed nerve endings and from reflex spasms of the internal anal sphincter.  This sphincter spasm further reduces blood flow to the posterior anal canal, thereby impairing healing and predisposing to chronic fissure development (eg, symptoms >8 weeks).  Chronic fissures are often less acutely painful but may exhibit features such as hypertrophied anal papillae, fibrotic edges, and sentinel skin tags.

Clinical presentation



Characteristic signs and symptoms of an anal fissure include:



  • Painful defecation:  Sharp, burning pain during (and after) bowel movements.
  • Rectal bleeding:  Usually minor and described as streaks of bright red blood on the surface of the stool or on toilet paper/wipes.
  • Perianal itching or irritation.
  • Visible linear tear in the anal mucosa:  Can be visualized with gentle traction of the buttocks.

Differential diagnosis



  • Hemorrhoids:  Typically cause painless, bright red rectal bleeding during bowel movements.  They are usually not painful unless thrombosed, in which case they classically appear as a purple-blue, firm, tender mass at the anal verge.
  • Perianal abscess:  Presents with localized pain, swelling, and erythema near the anus.  A tender, fluctuant mass is usually palpable, and systemic symptoms such as fever or malaise may be present.
  • Anorectal carcinoma:  May manifest with rectal bleeding, anal discomfort, or a sensation of fullness, but does not typically cause sharp, tearing pain with defecation.  A palpable or visual mass may be found on examination, especially in advanced disease.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of anal fissure is usually made clinically.  Physical examination typically reveals a superficial linear tear, most commonly in the posterior midline of the anal verge.  Digital rectal examination and anoscopy are often deferred (unless under anesthesia) due to significant pain.



Upon visualizing an anal fissure, further evaluation is typically not necessary.  However, additional work-up should be considered in the following circumstances, which suggest a secondary etiology of fissure:



  • Atypical fissure features:  Lateral or anterior location, multiple fissures, painless or unusually deep fissures, or recurrent lesions.
  • Significant hematochezia (eg, frank rectal bleeding):  Must consider other potential sources of bleeding (eg, colorectal cancer).
  • Lack of response to medical therapy after 6-8 weeks.


Anoscopy, sigmoidoscopy, and/or colonoscopy are typically indicated in these cases.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies



The following laboratory tests may be obtained in patients with atypical, nonhealing fissures:



  • Serology for sexually transmitted infection (eg, syphilis, HIV, herpes).
  • Biopsy to rule out malignancy.


Imaging (eg, CT, MRI) is not typically necessary unless there is concern for Crohn disease complications (eg, fistula, abscess) or to evaluate for an invasive carcinoma.

Management



The initial management of anal fissures includes:



  • Dietary modifications (eg, high-fiber diet, increased fluid intake) to reduce constipation.
  • Stool softeners (eg, docusate sodium) and laxatives (eg, polyethylene glycol) to ease stool passage.
  • Sitz baths (warm water soak several times daily) to increase blood flow to the injured mucosa.
  • Topical anesthetics (eg, lidocaine) to provide pain relief.
  • Topical vasodilators (eg, nifedipine, nitroglycerin) to reduce pressure in the anal sphincter and increase blood flow to the area, which improves symptoms and speeds healing.
  • Botulinum toxin injection into the anal area:  Alleviates sphincter spasm and results in rapid healing.  It is recommended for patients refractory to topical nitroglycerin/nifedipine.


Chronic anal fissures (present for >8 weeks) or fissures that are unresponsive to conservative management should undergo surgical repair with a lateral internal sphincterotomy, which eliminates hypertonia of the internal sphincter and is the gold standard for chronic, refractory fissures.  Less commonly, anal dilation, the gradual dilation of the sphincter, is performed to provide a wider aperture for the passage of stool and to interrupt spasms, but it can lead to fecal incontinence.

Prognosis



Acute anal fissures often heal within a few weeks with conservative measures.  Individuals who develop chronic fissures often require prolonged pharmacologic treatment or surgical intervention.  Surgery yields high cure rates (~90%) within several weeks.



Anal fissures can be prevented by maintaining regular bowel habits (eg, increased fiber and fluid intake), avoiding straining and anal trauma, and treating underlying conditions (eg, Crohn disease).

Summary



Anal fissures (

) are superficial tears in the anal mucosa, most commonly caused by mechanical trauma during defecation.  They typically present with pain and bright red bleeding during bowel movements.  Diagnosis is clinical and based on visualizing an anal laceration, most often in the posterior midline.  Further evaluation is typically unnecessary unless the fissure is atypically located, is associated with significant bleeding, or fails to heal with standard therapy.  Initial management includes dietary modifications, sitz baths, and topical vasodilatory/anesthetic agents.  Chronic or refractory fissures may require surgical intervention.
